channel.title: Nature
channel.description: Nature is the foremost international weekly scientific journal in the world and is the flagship journal for Nature Portfolio. It publishes the finest peer-reviewed research in all fields of science and technology on the basis of its originality, importance, interdisciplinary interest, timeliness, accessibility, elegance and surprising conclusions. Nature publishes landmark papers, award winning news, leading comment and expert opinion on important, topical scientific news and events that enable readers to share the latest discoveries in science and evolve the discussion amongst the global scientific community.
channel.dc:rights: © 2023 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.
channel.prism:copyright: © 2023 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.

item.title: Trove of new coronaviruses uncovered in bats — but threat is unclear
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02151-1

Horseshoe bats carry viruses closely related to SARS-CoV-2, but they probably can’t spread in people yet.
item.dc:title: Trove of new coronaviruses uncovered in bats — but threat is unclear
item.dc:creator: Ewen Callaway

item.title: Mars mission snaps striking ultraviolet view — image of the week
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02156-w

The spacecraft is boosting understanding of the Martian surface and atmosphere.
item.dc:title: Mars mission snaps striking ultraviolet view — image of the week

item.title: What happens when you microwave that plastic bowl?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02091-w

Tests show that certain types of plasticware give off high levels of microscopic plastic particles when heated in an microwave oven.
item.dc:title: What happens when you microwave that plastic bowl?

item.title: Stop talking about tomorrow’s AI doomsday when AI poses risks today
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02094-7

Talk of artificial intelligence destroying humanity plays into the tech companies’ agenda, and hinders effective regulation of the societal harms AI is causing right now.
item.dc:title: Stop talking about tomorrow’s AI doomsday when AI poses risks today

item.title: How to make your scientific data accessible, discoverable and useful
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01929-7

Specialists offer seven tips for effectively sharing your data.
item.dc:title: How to make your scientific data accessible, discoverable and useful
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey M. Perkel

item.title: Hundreds file suit targeting Mexico’s divisive science law
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02062-1

Scientists and some opposing lawmakers say the passing of the legislation violated normal procedures.
item.dc:title: Hundreds file suit targeting Mexico’s divisive science law
item.dc:creator: Myriam Vidal Valero

item.title: Long COVID: answers emerge on how many people get better
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02121-7

Studies are shedding light on rates of recovery as well as the prevention and treatment of the complex condition.
item.dc:title: Long COVID: answers emerge on how many people get better
item.dc:creator: Michael Marshall

item.title: Helping to protect elephants — using software
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02039-0

Jes Lefcourt aims to guard African wildlife by creating a real-time tracking software.
item.dc:title: Helping to protect elephants — using software
item.dc:creator: Hannah Docter-Loeb

item.title: Dolphin mums whistle ‘baby talk’ with their calves
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02089-4

The calls of dolphin mothers had a higher pitch when they were accompanied by their young.
item.dc:title: Dolphin mums whistle ‘baby talk’ with their calves

item.title: Did our human ancestors eat each other? Carved-up bone offers clues
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02082-x

A fossilized hominin leg shows gashes that were probably made by stone tools.
item.dc:title: Did our human ancestors eat each other? Carved-up bone offers clues
item.dc:creator: Lilly Tozer

item.title: How to hatch, brew and craft the perfect maths partnership
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02038-1

Mathematicians and their collaborators discuss the joys and challenges of working together on projects in science and the arts.
item.dc:title: How to hatch, brew and craft the perfect maths partnership
item.dc:creator: Rachel Crowell

item.title: Don’t get mad, get equal: putting an end to misogyny in science
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02101-x

Subtle forms of misogyny attack female leadership and coerce women to conform to conventional gender norms. It’s time to call out these behaviours, say Alison Bentley and Rachael Garrett.
item.dc:title: Don’t get mad, get equal: putting an end to misogyny in science
item.dc:creator: Alison Bentley
Rachael Garrett

item.title: Beyond Ozempic: brand-new obesity drugs will be cheaper and more effective
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02092-9

Hormone mimics offer advantages even beyond those of the potent weight-loss jabs on the market now.
item.dc:title: Beyond Ozempic: brand-new obesity drugs will be cheaper and more effective
item.dc:creator: Saima Sidik

item.title: Why phage viruses could be the key to treating deadly infections — if they can be harnessed safely
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01982-2

Interest is growing in how little-known viruses could be used to overcome drug-resistant bacteria.
item.dc:title: Why phage viruses could be the key to treating deadly infections — if they can be harnessed safely
item.dc:creator: Heidi Ledford

item.title: How ‘research impact bonds’ could transform science funding
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02070-1

Current funding models have high risks and low accountability. Public–private partnerships offer a better way.
item.dc:title: How ‘research impact bonds’ could transform science funding
item.dc:creator: Michael Hill

item.title: Decades-long bet on consciousness ends — and it’s philosopher 1, neuroscientist 0
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02120-8

Christof Koch wagered David Chalmers 25 years ago that researchers would learn how the brain achieves consciousness by now. But the quest continues.
item.dc:title: Decades-long bet on consciousness ends — and it’s philosopher 1, neuroscientist 0
item.dc:creator: Mariana Lenharo

item.title: The ocean’s engine, and the science of reading: Books in brief
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 23 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02097-4

Andrew Robinson reviews five of the best science picks.
item.dc:title: The ocean’s engine, and the science of reading: Books in brief
item.dc:creator: Andrew Robinson

item.title: Two Titan submersible passengers were prominent science philanthropists in Pakistan
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 23 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02100-y

Among those who died when the submersible imploded were Shahzada Dawood and his son Suleman, whose family are significant funders of science and education.
item.dc:title: Two Titan submersible passengers were prominent science philanthropists in Pakistan
item.dc:creator: Miryam Naddaf
Ehsan Masood

item.title: Huge leap in breast cancer survival rate
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 23 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02075-w

Women diagnosed since 2010 have a much lower risk of dying than those diagnosed in the 1990s.
item.dc:title: Huge leap in breast cancer survival rate
item.dc:creator: Katharine Sanderson

item.title: Universities urged to improve how staff sexual-assault claims are handled
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 23 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02099-2

Early-career researchers are often poorly served when they come forward, says the author of a report investigating the response to #MeToo at UK institutions.
item.dc:title: Universities urged to improve how staff sexual-assault claims are handled
item.dc:creator: Anne Gulland

item.title: Women in engineering: using hydrology to manage Jordan’s scarce water
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 23 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02073-y

Esraa Tarawneh says research and data gathering can improve her country’s resilience to droughts and rare flash floods.
item.dc:title: Women in engineering: using hydrology to manage Jordan’s scarce water
item.dc:creator: Jacqui Thornton

item.title: Women in engineering: giving Porsche 911s the ‘ultimate’ makeover
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 23 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02071-0

As a child, Imogen Howarth enjoyed solving problems and playing with cars. Now, she helps to redesign a classic and acts as a role model for aspiring female engineers.
item.dc:title: Women in engineering: giving Porsche 911s the ‘ultimate’ makeover
item.dc:creator: Jacqui Thornton

item.title: After Roe v. Wade: dwindling US abortion access is harming health a year later
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 23 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02083-w

Researchers are monitoring the consequences of the Supreme Court abolishing the right to an abortion.
item.dc:title: After Roe v. Wade: dwindling US abortion access is harming health a year later
item.dc:creator: Mariana Lenharo

item.title: Daily briefing: Urban living diminishes microbiome diversity
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 23 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02127-1

The hunter-gatherer lifestyle fosters a thriving gut microbiome. Plus, how Ukraine plans to move on from war and Soviet-era science.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: Urban living diminishes microbiome diversity
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: Underwater volcano triggered the most intense lightning ever recorded
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01943-9

The huge eruption of the Hunga Tonga–Hunga Ha‘apai volcano generated more than 2,600 lightning flashes per minute.
item.dc:title: Underwater volcano triggered the most intense lightning ever recorded

item.title: Is Fukushima wastewater release safe? What the science says
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02057-y

Radiation in the water will be diluted to almost-background levels, but some researchers are not sure this will be sufficient to mitigate the risks.
item.dc:title: Is Fukushima wastewater release safe? What the science says
item.dc:creator: Bianca Nogrady

item.title: War shattered Ukrainian science — its rebirth is now taking shape
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02031-8

The war is far from over but Ukraine’s government is already considering how to build back — and use the opportunity to move on from a Soviet-era system.
item.dc:title: War shattered Ukrainian science — its rebirth is now taking shape
item.dc:creator: Nisha Gaind
Layal Liverpool

item.title: Daily briefing: Y chromosome affects cancer risk
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02086-7

How the Y chromosome makes some cancers more deadly for men. Plus, what the science says about releasing Fukushima’s wastewater and a ‘duct tape for surgery’ inspired by barnacle glue wins Spinoff Prize.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: Y chromosome affects cancer risk
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: By the numbers: China’s changing diet
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02060-3

Data show that the Chinese middle class is eating a higher-fat, less-healthy diet — a trend reflected in the increases in heart disease and childhood obesity.
item.dc:title: By the numbers: China’s changing diet
item.dc:creator: Yvaine Ye
Jack Leeming

item.title: Hunter-gatherer lifestyle fosters thriving gut microbiome
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02065-y

Samples from the Tanzanian Hadza group included species previously unknown to science.
item.dc:title: Hunter-gatherer lifestyle fosters thriving gut microbiome
item.dc:creator: Gemma Conroy

item.title: A CRISPR-based method makes T cells that thwart teens’ cancer
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01945-7

A technique called base editing has been used for the first time to treat human disease.
item.dc:title: A CRISPR-based method makes T cells that thwart teens’ cancer

item.title: Why bladder cancer cells that shed their Y chromosome become more aggressive
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02069-8

Researchers uncover how loss of this chromosome helps cancer cells evade the immune system, and engineering synthetic cartilage.
item.dc:title: Why bladder cancer cells that shed their Y chromosome become more aggressive
item.dc:creator: Shamini Bundell
Nick Petrić Howe

item.title: Fabric warms or cools the body at the flick of a switch
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01946-6

Methods inspired by the Japanese paper art kirigami help to create a textile that moves with the body.
item.dc:title: Fabric warms or cools the body at the flick of a switch

item.title: A mucus-eating microbe controls the gut’s cholesterol factory
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01944-8

An elusive member of the gut microbiota can reduce cholesterol synthesis in the intestine.
item.dc:title: A mucus-eating microbe controls the gut’s cholesterol factory

item.title: Origin and evolutionary malleability of T cell receptor α diversity
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06218-x

TCRα repertoire diversity is best explained by species-specific extents of sequence microhomologies marking the ends of recombining elements, and germline sequence composition of rearranging elements determines the degree of diversity of somatically generated antigen receptors.
item.dc:title: Origin and evolutionary malleability of T cell receptor α diversity
item.dc:creator: Orlando B. Giorgetti
Connor P. O’Meara
Michael Schorpp
Thomas Boehm

item.title: Cartilage-like protein hydrogels engineered via entanglement
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06037-0

The introduction of chain entanglements into protein-based hydrogels yields hydrogels with high stiffness, high toughness, fast recovery and ultrahigh compressive strength, with mechanical properties close to those of cartilage.
item.dc:title: Cartilage-like protein hydrogels engineered via entanglement
item.dc:creator: Linglan Fu
Lan Li
Qingyuan Bian
Bin Xue
Jing Jin
Jiayu Li
Yi Cao
Qing Jiang
Hongbin Li

item.title: Quantum-limited optical time transfer for future geosynchronous links
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06032-5

Laser-based time transfer with near quantum-limited acquisition and timing is demonstrated that can support femtosecond precision over 102 dB link loss, more than sufficient for future time transfer to geosynchronous orbits for future optical clock networks.
item.dc:title: Quantum-limited optical time transfer for future geosynchronous links
item.dc:creator: Emily D. Caldwell
Jean-Daniel Deschenes
Jennifer Ellis
William C. Swann
Benjamin K. Stuhl
Hugo Bergeron
Nathan R. Newbury
Laura C. Sinclair

item.title: Structure and function of the RAD51B–RAD51C–RAD51D–XRCC2 tumour suppressor
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06179-1

Structural and biochemical studies of the RAD51B–RAD51C–RAD51D–XRCC2 complex reveal that it uses coupled RAD51B and RAD51C ATPase activities to promote the nucleation and extension of RAD51 nucleoprotein filaments.
item.dc:title: Structure and function of the RAD51B–RAD51C–RAD51D–XRCC2 tumour suppressor
item.dc:creator: Luke A. Greenhough
Chih-Chao Liang
Ondrej Belan
Simone Kunzelmann
Sarah Maslen
Monica C. Rodrigo-Brenni
Roopesh Anand
Mark Skehel
Simon J. Boulton
Stephen C. West

item.title: Single-cell quantification of ribosome occupancy in early mouse development
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06228-9

A single-cell ribosome profiling method can provide data at the level of allele-specific ribosome engagement in early development.
item.dc:title: Single-cell quantification of ribosome occupancy in early mouse development
item.dc:creator: Hakan Ozadam
Tori Tonn

Can Cenik

item.title: Structural insights into BCDX2 complex function in homologous recombination
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06219-w

Analyses of the structure and biochemical properties of the tetrameric complex of RAD51B, RAD51C, RAD51D and XRCC2 reveal details of its role in the repair of DNA double-strand breaks.
item.dc:title: Structural insights into BCDX2 complex function in homologous recombination
item.dc:creator: Yashpal Rawal

item.title: Realization of a fractional quantum Hall state with ultracold atoms
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06122-4

Using ultracold atoms trapped in an optical lattice, a Laughlin-like fractional quantum Hall state is prepared and mapped out on a microscopic level.
item.dc:title: Realization of a fractional quantum Hall state with ultracold atoms
item.dc:creator: Julian Léonard
Sooshin Kim
Joyce Kwan
Perrin Segura
Fabian Grusdt
Cécile Repellin
Nathan Goldman
Markus Greiner

item.title: Histone demethylase KDM5D upregulation drives sex differences in colon cancer
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06254-7

A murine colorectal cancer (CRC) model shows that mutant KRAS-STAT4-mediated upregulation of Y chromosome KDM5D contributes to the sex differences in KRAS-mutant CRC, providing an actionable therapeutic strategy for metastasis risk reduction for men afflicted with KRAS-mutant CRC.
item.dc:title: Histone demethylase KDM5D upregulation drives sex differences in colon cancer
item.dc:creator: Jiexi Li

item.title: Physiology and diseases of tissue-resident macrophages
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06002-x

This Review addresses the current understanding of the roles of tissue-resident macrophages in physiology and disease, including their development and their functions in tissue remodelling and nutrient recycling.
item.dc:title: Physiology and diseases of tissue-resident macrophages
item.dc:creator: Tomi Lazarov
Sergio Juarez-Carreño
Nehemiah Cox
Frederic Geissmann

item.title: Injury prevents Ras mutant cell expansion in mosaic skin
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06198-y

Following skin injury, wild-type epithelial cells outcompete oncogenic Ras G12V mutant cells owing to differential activation of the EGFR signalling pathway during injury repair.
item.dc:title: Injury prevents Ras mutant cell expansion in mosaic skin
item.dc:creator: Sara Gallini
Karl Annusver
Nur-Taz Rahman

Valentina Greco

item.title: Relaxed targeting rules help PIWI proteins silence transposons
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06257-4

Of the two types of Argonaute proteins produced by animals, AGO and PIWI, PIWI proteins can bind RNAs with less complementarity, enabling efficient silencing of transposons without the need to produce new RNA guides.
item.dc:title: Relaxed targeting rules help PIWI proteins silence transposons
item.dc:creator: Ildar Gainetdinov

item.title: B-cell-specific checkpoint molecules that regulate anti-tumour immunity
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06231-0

Manipulation of TIM-1-expressing B cells enables engagement of the second arm of adaptive immunity to promote anti-tumour immunity and inhibit tumour growth.
item.dc:title: B-cell-specific checkpoint molecules that regulate anti-tumour immunity

item.title: Entropic repulsion of cholesterol-containing layers counteracts bioadhesion
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06033-4

Entropic repulsion caused by interfacial orientational fluctuations of cholesterol layers restricts protein adsorption and bacterial adhesion, providing a conceptually new physicochemical perspective on biointerfaces that may guide future material design in regulation of adhesion.
item.dc:title: Entropic repulsion of cholesterol-containing layers counteracts bioadhesion
item.dc:creator: Jens Friedrichs
Ralf Helbig
Julia Hilsenbeck
Prithvi Raj Pandey
Jens-Uwe Sommer
Lars David Renner
Tilo Pompe
Carsten Werner

item.title: PD-1 maintains CD8 T cell tolerance towards cutaneous neoantigens
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06217-y

A mouse model expressing T cell antigens in the skin epidermis is used to demonstrate that local self-tolerance is maintained by PD-1, which prevents terminal CD8 T cell differentiation, effector molecule secretion and access to antigen-expressing cells.
item.dc:title: PD-1 maintains CD8 T cell tolerance towards cutaneous neoantigens
item.dc:creator: Martina Damo

item.title: Signalling by senescent melanocytes hyperactivates hair growth
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06172-8

Senescent melanocytes of skin nevi drive hyperactivation of hair growth through the signalling factor SPP1.
item.dc:title: Signalling by senescent melanocytes hyperactivates hair growth

item.title: Intricate 3D architecture of a DNA mimic of GFP
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06229-8

X-ray crystallography and cryo-electron microscopy analyses of Lettuce—a DNA mimic of GFP—bound to various fluorophores reveal previously unknown structures of DNA that rival analogous RNAs in complexity.
item.dc:title: Intricate 3D architecture of a DNA mimic of GFP
item.dc:creator: Luiz F. M. Passalacqua
Michael T. Banco
Jared D. Moon
Xing Li
Samie R. Jaffrey
Adrian R. Ferré-D’Amaré

item.title: X-ray polarization evidence for a 200-year-old flare of Sgr A<sup>*</sup>
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06064-x

A study reports the measurement of the polarization degree and angle of X-rays from Sagittarius A* reflected off a nearby cloud, indicating an X-ray flare about 200 years ago.
item.dc:title: X-ray polarization evidence for a 200-year-old flare of Sgr A<sup>*</sup>

item.title: Oriented nucleation in formamidinium perovskite for photovoltaics
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06208-z

The black phase of formamidinium lead iodide perovskite is used to make highly efficient solar cells, and a technique to improve its purity and stability by controlling crystal nucleation could make them even better.
item.dc:title: Oriented nucleation in formamidinium perovskite for photovoltaics
item.dc:creator: Pengju Shi

item.title: A second wave of topological phenomena in photonics and acoustics
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06163-9

The current state of the art of topological phenomena in photonics and acoustics is reviewed and future research directions for valuable applications are discussed.
item.dc:title: A second wave of topological phenomena in photonics and acoustics
item.dc:creator: Xiujuan Zhang
Farzad Zangeneh-Nejad
Ze-Guo Chen
Ming-Hui Lu
Johan Christensen

item.title: Y chromosome loss in cancer drives growth by evasion of adaptive immunity
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06234-x

Loss of the Y chromosome in tumour cells is associated with a poor prognosis for patients with bladder cancer by causing local T cell exhaustion, which also increases the response to immune checkpoint blockade therapy.
item.dc:title: Y chromosome loss in cancer drives growth by evasion of adaptive immunity
item.dc:creator: Hany A. Abdel-Hafiz
Johanna M. Schafer
Xingyu Chen
Tong Xiao
Timothy D. Gauntner
Zihai Li
Dan Theodorescu

item.title: Structural basis of mitochondrial protein import by the TIM23 complex
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06239-6

The cryo-electron microscopy structure of the mitochondrial TIM23 complex from Saccharomyces cerevisiae shows that Tim17 forms a protein translocation path.
item.dc:title: Structural basis of mitochondrial protein import by the TIM23 complex
item.dc:creator: Sue Im Sim
Yuanyuan Chen
Diane L. Lynch
James C. Gumbart
Eunyong Park

item.title: Magical meeting: a collaboration to tackle child malnutrition in Bangladesh
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02061-2

A conference conversation between gut microbiome researcher Jeffrey Gordon and physcian Tahmeed Ahmed forged an award-winning international partnership.
item.dc:title: Magical meeting: a collaboration to tackle child malnutrition in Bangladesh

item.title: Cholesterol can make surfaces non-stick
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01681-y

Surfaces that contain cholesterol, such as the skin of some invertebrates, can repel other molecules, preventing the adsorption of proteins and bacteria. Experiments, simulations and thermodynamic analyses show that this repulsive quality depends on cholesterol molecules rotating freely and switching their orientation.
item.dc:title: Cholesterol can make surfaces non-stick

item.title: Daily briefing: Toxic noise — how to tackle harmful noise pollution
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02078-7

How countries and cities treat the epidemic of noise. Plus, battles over funding could threaten the historic effort to save species and open-source AI chatbots offer alternatives to ChatGPT.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: Toxic noise — how to tackle harmful noise pollution
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: More carrot, less stick: how to make research assessments fairer
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01990-2

Research-assessment exercises are often misused to judge researchers or cut their funding — changes to the United Kingdom’s scheme are a promising start.
item.dc:title: More carrot, less stick: how to make research assessments fairer

item.title: Current conservation policies risk accelerating biodiversity loss
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01979-x

Three approaches that aim to cut the harms of agriculture — land sharing, rewilding and organic farming — risk driving up food imports and causing environmental damage overseas. An alternative approach is both effective and cheaper.
item.dc:title: Current conservation policies risk accelerating biodiversity loss
item.dc:creator: Ian Bateman
Andrew Balmford

item.title: Lost Titanic sub: an ocean scientist talks about dive safety
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02074-x

Oceanographer Peter Girguis offers an insider view of deep-sea exploration.
item.dc:title: Lost Titanic sub: an ocean scientist talks about dive safety
item.dc:creator: Katharine Sanderson

item.title: Excerpts from after-action interviews regarding the incident at Penn Station
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01991-1

A hidden menace.
item.dc:title: Excerpts from after-action interviews regarding the incident at Penn Station
item.dc:creator: Ron Fein

item.title: Invasive palms and WWII damaged an island paradise. Could fungi help to restore it?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01932-y

Researchers ventured to the world’s most remote island to study how fungi in soils could help to revive damaged ecosystems.
item.dc:title: Invasive palms and WWII damaged an island paradise. Could fungi help to restore it?
item.dc:creator: Virginia Gewin

item.title: Clocks synchronized at the quantum limit
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01937-7

Time signals have been transmitted across 300 kilometres with an accuracy and precision limited only by the quantum nature of photons. The feat promises to revolutionize high-precision science using satellites.
item.dc:title: Clocks synchronized at the quantum limit
item.dc:creator: David Gozzard

item.title: Uncovering a role for B cells in antitumour immunity
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01678-7

The function of immune cells called B cells in cancer has been controversial. Single-cell profiling has identified a previously undescribed subset of B cells that express a protein called TIM-1 and that multiply in response to melanoma tumour growth. Deletion of the gene that encodes TIM-1 in these cells unleashed an antitumour immune response.
item.dc:title: Uncovering a role for B cells in antitumour immunity
